topic_metadata.title: How to scale without adding line breaks?

posts.name: AJ Rush
posts.cooked:
I would expect these two lines …

Hello #scale(300%, reflow: true)[World]!
Hello #text(size: 3em)[World]!

… to have the same result. However, they don’t.

IMG_5570956×879 81.5 KB

Instead, the scale function seems to be putting line breaks before and after itself. How do I prevent this?

posts.cooked:
@LordBaryhobal, as a nitpick, you should use Markdown language so that the code doesn’t look green:

````md
```typ
your code
```
````
example 
```typ
your code
```

Additionally, if the scale() is used multiple times, then it’s better to move repetitive named arguments into a set rule:

#set scale(reflow: true)

Hello #box(scale(300%)[World])!

Or you can make a wrapper:

#let scale(scale, body) = box(std.scale(scale, reflow: true, body))

Hello #scale(300%)[World]!

For the reflow: true see these:

`rotate` doesn't work as expected when `reflow: true`

opened 10:40PM - 03 Nov 24 UTC
Andrew15-5
bug layout

### Description As I showed in https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/5330#issueco…mment-2449809323, in v0.12.0 to rotate overshoots the size of the content for most degrees when `rotate(reflow: true)`. Previously it was doing the opposite: https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/5330#issuecomment-2452044452. As a result, in never worked as expected, and we need to fix that. At least for the majority of use cases. ```typ #set rotate(reflow: true) #set page(height: 80pt, width: 120pt, fill: gray) #place(block(width: 100%, height: 100%, fill: green)) #align(center + horizon, rotate(59deg, image("images/tiger.jpg"))) ``` This blocks https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/5330 that supposed to fix https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/5327. I'm not sure, but `scale` and `skew` could have the same problem. ### Reproduction URL _No response_ ### Operating system Linux ### Typst version - [X] I am using the latest version of Typst

Additionally, if the `scale()` is used multiple times, then it's better to move repetitive named arguments into a set rule:

```typ
#set scale(reflow: true)

Hello #box(scale(300%)[World])!
```

Or you can make a wrapper:

```typ
#let scale(scale, body) = box(std.scale(scale, reflow: true, body))

Hello #scale(300%)[World]!
```

For the `reflow: true` see these:

https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/5327
